document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools – March 2015

EE378AFB1B7A4A2C94077070300E59D7.description:
explaining scientific and technological changes and evaluating their impact on
American culture.

78B6ECAA09654F9EB657A2E94E1D6F33.description:
evaluating the evolving and changing role of government, including its role in the
American economy; and

FD811EEE2EF24AC7A89E4B35A3E810A1.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand political and social conditions
in the United States during the early twenty-first century by

EB198EFBB7774D32BF1DF908C6244F4B.description: evaluating and explaining the changes that occurred in American culture.

E9652051285B47DD9F917AA4198AFDA5.description: explaining how scientific and technological advances altered American lives; and

2B0CA80C33B547EF8CA727558E76F719.description:
evaluating and explaining the foreign and domestic policies pursued by the
American government after the Cold War;

19DD617474D24747BACAF58223ADDCB6.description: analyzing changes in immigration policy and the impact of increased immigration;

9C21035B56F3458A9795A361BBB6494D.description:
explaining how the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
(NAACP), the 1963 March on Washington, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the
Voting Rights Act of 1965, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) had an
impact on all Americans;

D32FB5D2B55B4EDDB40DA3740B1C4FBF.description: explaining the factors that led to United States expansion;

2BB814E1E1364BE0B3AB1B5AE76CBBAA.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the social, political, and
cultural movements and changes in the United States during the second half of the
twentieth century by

E48F6634D15745A5A5AB8617CBC620C6.description:
evaluating and explaining the factors that caused the collapse of communism in
Europe and how it changed American foreign policy, including the role of Ronald
Reagan.

D0147AB2739B496794C621351E2C36C1.description: analyzing the domestic impact of the Cold War; and

75887617D58A496CB435B7A749C4B1B7.description:
evaluating and explaining how policy changes impacted the United States’
relationships in Latin America;

F5D35A71F135433A91E9D04698E0064A.description:
analyzing the changing role of the United States in Asia, including Korea, Vietnam,
and China;

1B62BA3A73104BB781DE2863BB36888B.description:
analyzing the efforts of the United States to protect Western Europe, including the
role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO);

39290DC45917462990EAE322D09E3CB8.description:
locating and explaining the political boundary changes, and the formation of the
United Nations and the Marshall Plan;

6FE563F36EBC4206BDD1446F1F9C75BD.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the United States’ foreign
policy during the Cold War era by

13C0F32921D4494E8AB9DBE2772F851D.description: The United States since World War II

C3595C5AB6874B6E808181C390B0529B.description:
evaluating and explaining the treatment of prisoners of war and civilians by the
Allied and Axis powers.

E61C356301A14329B943004BB8F80DED.description:
analyzing the Holocaust (Hitler’s “final solution”), its impact on Jews and other
groups, and the postwar trials of war criminals; and

1D352B70C5154A91865E008BBBC8877C.description:
evaluating and explaining how the United States mobilized its economic and
military resources, including the role of all-minority military units (the Tuskegee
Airmen and Nisei regiments) and the contributions of media, minorities, and
women to the war effort;

A3ED2B14E60149B0A6E0B917790C3FB5.description: describing and locating the major battles and key leaders of the Pacific theater;

CEA7A15EA85A41AFAA631650F2549FFA.description: describing and locating the major battles and key leaders of the European theater;

E1E2C1B43C80467DA03621030D9058FF.description:
analyzing the causes and events that led to American involvement in the war,
including the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and the American response;

69CE71807F36403F8C609DF81DE0CE99.description: The student will apply social science skills to understand World War II by

9A4584B1DCC94DC799B765A2C8E5B645.description:
evaluating and explaining how Franklin D. Roosevelt’s New Deal measures
addressed the Great Depression and expanded the government’s role in the
economy.

4175391EA1994EDEB0B5A2648C005C13.description:
explaining the causes of the Great Depression and its impact on the American
people; and

C3817A2D218A47C5837903A9A3C26642.description:
assessing and explaining the economic causes and consequences of the stock market
crash of 1929;

62D683FD035748AC870EA9D966B0C318.description: analyzing how popular culture evolved and challenged traditional values;

FFC8E20CA91E4B239EF491C579A2270E.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand key events during the 1920s
and 1930s by

02198C764C61426B9271545B82696FEC.description:
evaluating and explaining the terms of the Treaty of Versailles, with emphasis on
the national debate in response to the League of Nations.

1989A78524E64FD3992739001CA5DEAF.description:
evaluating the United States’ involvement in World War I, including Wilson’s
Fourteen Points; and

C7B8BBA8E1FF4D3AB27D6FBBCA883107.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the emerging role of the
United States in world affairs during the end of the nineteenth and early twentieth
centuries by

A10B7827F0144BFD8467939F6C06A8F5.description: Emergence of Modern America and World Conflicts

F01E0EFECC804A708EB175447C7B589B.description:
evaluating and explaining the economic outcomes and the political, cultural and
social developments of the Progressive Movement and the impact of its legislation.

76D1338F17724C4DB9FF9D3AC7B0E7FF.description:
evaluating and explaining the social and cultural impact of industrialization,
including rapid urbanization; and

8D56E3620DA5440BAF2C22708E247F8F.description:
examining the contributions of new immigrants and evaluating the challenges they
faced, including anti-immigration legislation;

A8ACDDC9CC5842D0BA71F4599FD11F2E.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand how the nation grew and
changed from the end of Reconstruction through the early twentieth century by

9DD63649347A4FAA8C3BBFB0DC8932C6.description:
evaluating and explaining the political and economic impact of the war and
Reconstruction, including the adoption of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to
the Constitution of the United States.

88B901447DCE466C99CF40A4E90FA197.description:
evaluating postwar Reconstruction plans presented by key leaders of the Civil War;
and

084D0077F24549C6A1A9F88B6C47F783.description:
evaluating and explaining the impact of the war on Americans, with emphasis on
Virginians, African Americans, the common soldier, and the home front;

DDF85C238F554FE1999192DD2F30DDA9.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the Civil War and
Reconstruction eras and their significance as major turning points in American history
by

DB7C031CD6BB4EE79A60EAD5208C911D.description:
evaluating and explaining the multiple causes and compromises leading to the Civil
War, including the role of the institution of slavery.

E4848CA7C0AF47EEBED15AEAC500DE4E.description:
explaining how Manifest Destiny and President James K. Polk’s policies impacted
the nation; and

49582C6D1D7041B4B8A2B5E39E8DC28C.description:
analyzing the social and cultural changes during the period, with emphasis on “the
age of the common man” (Jacksonian Era);

DDA2795A49674F2589F9159D3EB9D0A7.description:
assessing the political and economic changes that occurred during this period, with
emphasis on James Madison and the War of 1812;

98EA20B3F7F24D08A42134B5F8A84AA4.description: describing the political results of territorial expansion;

A08FF1387EED404F8AD0B7C7E245E706.description: explaining territorial expansion and its impact on the American Indians;

69EE22C95125460BA6616941FE3860D6.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand major events in Virginia and
United States history during the first half of the nineteenth century by

34D2C89A55E648678B85F5A7DD5AE6E4.description:
evaluating the impact of John Marshall’s precedent-setting decisions that
established the Supreme Court as an independent and equal branch of the national
government.

99982BFB41944172BC2905670B6AAB62.description:
assessing the arguments of Federalists and Anti-Federalists during the ratification
debates in defense of the principles and issues that led to the development of
political parties; and

5C1D20C19D764565BCC91B8B0F708960.description:
examining founding documents to explore the development of American
constitutional government, with emphasis on the significance of the Virginia
Declaration of Rights and the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom in the framing
of the Bill of Rights;

6A6789EAE90146D5A66FA964672FF043.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the development of the
American political system by

173B291562BA4F1CACF34B65A076453C.description:
evaluating how key principles in the Declaration of Independence grew in
importance to become unifying ideas of American political philosophy.

CF861F26BB234F1CB894FB165D9457B8.description:
analyzing the competing factors that led to colonial victory in the Revolutionary
War; and

677D332B1AFE4FDFB5B216BF037D5464.description:
explaining how conflicting loyalties created political differences among the
colonists concerning separation from Great Britain;

DD253C5083E24DF49C0267EDDE3166E5.description:
evaluating how political ideas of the Enlightenment helped shape American
politics;

7DF5C51733674B7AB35D06AC512621DE.description: describing the results of the French and Indian War;

2FBC613DD3094110B7B2285CF05B8EA5.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the issues and events leading
to and during the Revolutionary Period by

DFD6244A5CDB451BABF9D1DC625E0823.description:
explaining the impact of the development of indentured servitude and slavery in the
colonies.

1270A9ABF25140248007E75CB3C6E8AE.description: analyzing how social and political factors impacted the culture of the colonies; and

CD485D4D2B26481085C186B02149318D.description: evaluating the economic characteristics of the colonies;

AED2F41D25674151B3F0CE887A13CC0A.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand early European colonization
by

918EE884E7514082A2FF37C62C705495.description:
analyzing the cultural interactions among American Indians, Europeans, and
Africans.

5F383840874E452BBDC3F47D61D82571.description:
describing the characteristics of early exploration and evaluating the impact of
European settlement in the Americas; and

36C3F87868BC41669A6A2C5895938969.description:
The student will apply social science skills to understand the impact of the Age of
Exploration by

091FF04B612746E6AF988F5A3514BC5F.description: investigating and researching to develop products orally and in writing.

F4693DA4205B4597BECC3C5A0352CCC5.description:
identifying the rights and responsibilities of citizenship and ethical use of material
and intellectual property; and

719E191DAFF049A69168044A105637A8.description:
using a decision-making model to analyze and explain the incentives for and
consequences of a specific choice made;

279CC6D9A9754C8AB9A75C8A7620B2B7.description: analyzing multiple connections across time and place;

F102A52BACE746E3AF0A2A32AE458445.description:
explaining how indirect cause-and-effect relationships impact people, places, and
events in Virginia and United States history;

0EFA7FEF3850463E99292E5AF7D7913B.description:
comparing and contrasting historical, cultural, economic, and political perspectives
in Virginia and United States history;

363080C9687E4167ACD78E823DB2E217.description: constructing arguments, using evidence from multiple sources;

430AEDD02A334B18B3388D5698CAD977.description:
interpreting charts, graphs, and pictures to determine characteristics of people,
places, or events in Virginia and United States history;

15295D29EB5B432D94227EAF31CD4F01.description:
using geographic information to determine patterns and trends in Virginia and
United States history;

D327F76EFA664C6E8D99185E5DD10D03.description:
synthesizing evidence from artifacts and primary and secondary sources to obtain
information about events in Virginia and United States history;

26BC1CD7AE8A4833B2872F411B1E7A6E.description:
The student will demonstrate skills for historical thinking, geographical analysis,
economic decision making, and responsible citizenship by
